one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. From the past week's study, what made the most significant impact to you in the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read 2 Samuel 13.
David's son Amnon raped his half-sister Tamar, and his half-brother Absalom killed him.

questions.questionText: 3. a. What alarming signs do you see in Amnon's behavior? What sins did he commit? (See Exodus 20:1-17 and Leviticus 18:9.)
3. b. What do you learn about the devastation that follows unchecked sin? How can people establish safeguards to protect against sin from going this far?
4. What do you learn from the ways the men in this passage reacted to Tamar's rape? What did God's law require? (See Leviticus 18:9-11 and Deuteronomy 22:25-27.)
5. What scriptures emphasize God's comfort and compassion for the hurting and brokenhearted? How might these verses comfort you or others? (Use any Scripture reference.)

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read 2 Samuel 14-15:12.
Joab arranged Absalom's return to Israel and Absalom conspired to be king.

questions.questionText: 6. How did David's reluctance to act complicate his decisions and conflicts among his children?
7. What does Absalom's strategy to become king reveal about him?
8. How do you deal with difficult decisions and potential conflicts? How might you respond differently in the future?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read 2 Samuel 15:13-16:14 and Psalm 3.
David abandoned Jerusalem and endured betrayal and ridicule.

questions.questionText: 9. Why did David choose to leave Jerusalem? What do you learn about David from his interactions with people along the journey?
10. Describe what David did and how he must have felt when he learned his trusted advisor, Ahithophel, joined Absalom? (See Psalm 41:7-9.)
11. Describe David's submission to and trust in God. Which truths are comforting to you? Why?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read 2 Samuel 16:15-18:33.
Absalom's attempt to kill David resulted in his own death.

questions.questionText: 12. From 2 Samuel 16:15-23, how were Nathan's words fulfilled through Ahithophel's advice? (See 2 Samuel 12:11-12.)
13. From 2 Samuel 17:1-23, how was David's prayer answered? (See 2 Samuel 15:31.) What do you learn about God's prophecies and/or prayer?
14. What was David's response at the news of Absalom's death? What might have been going through his mind and heart?

six.title: SIXTH DAY: Review 2 Samuel 13-18 and Psalm 3.

questions.questionText: 15. What attribute of God resonated most from your study of this week's passage? How do you see that attribute displayed in the world today?
